Statistics

1. Collecting & organising data

Exercises

2. Line graphs & bar charts

Line graph

The line graph below represents the productivity of a factory making teddy bears:

  1. How many units were produced at 33 hours?

    Answer: units
    numeric
    STEP: <no title>
    [−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

    Line graphs compare two variables. Each variable is plotted along an axis. Here we plotted time on the vertical axis against the number of units produced on the horizontal axis. Line graphs are good at showing specific values of data, so if we are given one variable, we can easily determine the other. Put your finger on 33 hours and check which vertical value corresponds to this specific point. We can see that 1111 units were produced at 33 hours.

    Submit your answer as:

  2. At which point in time were 44 units produced ?

    Answer: hours
    numeric
    STEP: <no title>
    [−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

    In the same way here, if you put your finger on 44 units and check which horizontal value corresponds to this specific point, you can see that at 1313 hours , 44 units were produced.

    Submit your answer as:

  3. How long was the factory's workday?

    Answer: hours
    numeric
    STEP: <no title>
    [−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

    This is an easy one: just find the corresponding hour where the graph ends. In this case it was 1313 hours.

    Submit your answer as:

Bar chart

The following bar chart compares the average grades students achieved for three subjects over a range of years:

  1. What was the average grade in 2009 for Science ?
    Answer:

    The average grade for Science in 2009 was %%.

    numeric
    STEP: Read the answer from the graph
    [−2 points ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

    To find the average grade for Science in 2009, you need to look at the key at the bottom of the graph first. You are looking for Science: what color is Science? Now look for the year 2009: what is the average grade that corresponds with the height of Science? That is the answer ≈≈ 90%90%.

    Submit your answer as:
  2. During which year did students achieve the highest grade for Science?
    Answer:

    Students achieved the highest grade for Science in .

    string
    STEP: Read the answer from the graph
    [−2 points ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

    Again look at the key, what color is the subject Science? Now just look for the highest bar that represents Science and let you eyes go down towards the dates. Which date corresponds with the highest bar. That's right: the highest grade was achieved in the year 2011.

Bar chart

A school started a recycling project. The bar chart below shows how many of each item they recycled last week:

  1. Which item did the school collect the most of?
  2. From the recycled items, which item did the school collect 5 kg5 kg of?
  3. Which item did the school collected the least of?
Answer:
  1. The most collected item is .
  2. The item for which 5 kg5 kg were collected is .
  3. The least collected item is .
STEP: Read the relevant information from the chart
[−3 points ⇒ 0 / 3 points left]

A bar graph is a chart that uses either horizontal or vertical bars to show comparisons among categories. The length of each rectangular bar is proportional to the values that it represents. One axis of the chart shows the specific categories being compared, in this case the different categories of recycled materials and the other axis represents a discrete value. Do you remember what discrete data are? Discrete data usually have numeric values and the items can be counted.

  • From the graph we can see the category that was collected the most was glass. This is represented by the highest bar, which represents the highest value 1313.
  • To find the answer to the second question we need to focus on the axis with the frequency of items, the vertical axis. Find the value 55 and follow a horizontal line across until you reach the bar that corresponds with that value. In this case, it is textiles.
  • From the graph we can see the category that was collected the least was electronics. This is represented by the lowest bar, which represents the lowest value 11.
Submit your answer as: andand

3. Grouped frequency tables

Working with data sets: counting values

A group of 2020 students count the number of playing cards they each have. Here are the data values they collected:

19;3;10;1;1310;3;1;1;212;2;10;18;219;8;11;16;1719;3;10;1;1310;3;1;1;212;2;10;18;219;8;11;16;17

Count the number of students who have from 88 up to 1111 playing cards. In other words, how many students have playing cards in the following range: 8≤number of playing cards<128≤number of playing cards<12?

TIP: It will be helpful to organise the data into a table.
Answer:

The number of students with playing cards in that range is .

numeric
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

Start by arranging the numbers from smallest to largest. Then you can count how many of the values are in the range from 88 up to but not including 1212.

STEP: Sort the data and count how many values are in the range from 88 up to but not including 1212.
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

Firstly, we must sort the data values. This is not necessary, but it is the safest way to get the correct answer! In this case we want to group the values into intervals. A table is a good way to do this: we can sort the data into intervals which include the one we want.

The data values are:

19;3;10;1;1310;3;1;1;212;2;10;18;219;8;11;16;1719;3;10;1;1310;3;1;1;212;2;10;18;219;8;11;16;17

We can list these in the intervals shown below. The interval we want is shaded.

Interval Data values Frequency
0≤x<40≤x<4 3;1;3;1;1;2;2;23;1;3;1;1;2;2;2 88
4≤x<84≤x<8 NoneNone 00
8≤x<128≤x<12 10;10;10;8;1110;10;10;8;11 55
12≤x<1612≤x<16 13;1213;12 22
16≤x<2016≤x<20 19;18;19;16;1719;18;19;16;17 55

Note that the interval we want does not include data values equal to 1212!

STEP: Visualise the data on a histogram
[−0 points ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

We can see from the data list that the number of values in this range is 55.

NOTE:

We can represent the data on a histogram. The height of each bar is equal to the frequency values from the table above. The interval we are interested in for this question is shown in green.

The number of students with playing cards in the range: 8≤number of playing cards<128≤number of playing cards<12 is 5.

Submit your answer as:

Exercises

Working with data sets: counting values

A group of 1515 students count the number of stones they each have. Here are the data values they collected:

9;9;1;9;812;5;8;2;71;6;3;10;149;9;1;9;812;5;8;2;71;6;3;10;14

Count the number of students who have from 66 up to 88 stones. In other words, how many students have stones in the following range: 6≤number of stones<96≤number of stones<9?

TIP: It will be helpful to organise the data into a table.
Answer:

The number of students with stones in that range is .

HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

STEP: Sort the data and count how many values are in the range from 66 up to but not including 99.

The data values are:

9;9;1;9;812;5;8;2;71;6;3;10;149;9;1;9;812;5;8;2;71;6;3;10;14

We can list these in the intervals shown below. The interval we want is shaded.

Interval Data values Frequency
0≤x<30≤x<3 1;2;11;2;1 33
3≤x<63≤x<6 5;35;3 22
6≤x<96≤x<9 8;8;7;68;8;7;6 44

Working with data sets: counting values

Matching graphs and types of data

From what kind or kinds of data would a frequency polygon be generated?

A categorical only
B quantitative only
C one categorical and one quantitative
D varies according to situation
Answer:

The correct type of data for a frequency polygon is choice .

HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 2 / 2 points left]

Think about an example of a frequency polygon. What kinds of values go on the horizontal axis? What kinds of values go on the vertical axis?

STEP: Think about an example of a frequency polygon
[−2 points ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

The question asks us to identify what type of data are used in a frequency polygon. Is it based on categorical data, quantitative data, or both? Here is some information about these data types:

  • Categorical data are organised into categories. For example, if you count the number of schools in each province, the provinces are categories. There are nine categories and each school fits into one of them. One useful fact about categorical data is that you can change the order of the categories. For the provinces, you could order them alphabetically. Or you could start with the province where you live.
  • Quantitative data are organised numerically (as numbers). For example, the heights of all the students in a class are quantitative data. Quantitative data typically follow some order, like smallest to largest.

Frequency polygons are always based on quantitative data. So a frequency polygon shows us values which are organised into intervals of numbers.

Here is an example of a frequency polygon. It shows the total number of servings of fruit eaten in a one week period for 100100 different people. It is organised by the number of servings.

The frequency polygon above shows data about how many servings of fruit people ate. The data are organised by the number of servings. The values on the horizontal axis are in order from least to greatest, and we cannot change that. We cannot change it because the data are quantitative and continuous.

Here is the original table, with explanations for each choice.

A ✘ categorical only
False: A frequency polygon is not used for categorical data - the data must be continuous.
B ✔ quantitative only
True: A frequency polygon shows quantitative data on both axes.
C ✘ one categorical and one quantitative
False: A frequency polygon does not show categorical data.
D ✘ varies according to situation
False: A frequency polygon always shows quantitative data.

The correct answer is choice quantitative only.

Imagine a histogram for the results for a very difficult quiz with 1010 questions.

    2. What quantity should go on the yy-axis of the histogram?
    Answer:
    1. The quantity on the xx-axis should be: .

    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 2 / 2 points left]

    Reread the question. The yy-axis on a histogram always shows the number of data values (the frequency of values). The xx-axis always shows the values for the data themselves.

    STEP: Select the correct axis labels
    [−2 points ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

    This question is about making a histogram. Specifically, we need to figure out what quantities should go on the axes for a histogram about the situation in the question.

    The horizontal axis in a histogram must always show the possible values of the data. In this case the data values are the quiz results. So the xx-axis must show the marks.

    Submit your answer as: and

  2. Which of the pictures below shows the shape we should expect for the histogram? (Reminder: the data are about the results for a very difficult quiz with 1010 questions.)

    A

    B

    C

    D
    Answer:

    The most reasonable shape to expect is choice .

    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

    Do you expect most of the quiz results to be in the middle of the values, or will they mostly be smaller values? Or will they be spread out equally for all the values?

    STEP: Think about the way the data values will be spread out
    [−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

    To answer this question, we need to think about how the data values for the quiz results will be spread out.

    The four images below show these basic situations:

    A

    Balanced shape: Most data values are in the centre with a balanced number of values on each side. This means values in the middle are more common than values on the left side or the right side. So a balanced distribution is more or less symmetric with the peak in the middle.

    B

    Flat shape: All data values are spread out equally. So values on the left side are just as common as values on the right side and in the middle. This typically represents something random. Note that a flat shape is not exactly flat - but it has no significant peaks.

    C

    Skewed right shape: The data values are clumped up on the left side with a "tail" to the right. This shows that for some reason the data values on the right side are less common. This would happen if larger values (on the right side) are harder to achieve than smaller values (on the left side).

    D

    Skewed left shape: The data values are clumped up on the right side with a "tail" to the left. This shows that for some reason the data values on the left side are less common. This would happen if larger values (on the right side) are easier to achieve than smaller values (on the left side).

    So which of these is the most reasonable to expect? The question states that the quiz is very difficult. That means most of the students probably got pretty low marks, and not many students would get high marks. So the most likely shape for the real histogram is the skewed right shape.

    NOTE: It is possible that the histogram will have a different shape - we can't know for sure if we do not have the data values. So our answer is based on reasonable expectations about quiz results.

    Therefore the most reasonable shape to expect is choice C.

Locating a specific value in a histogram

The figure below shows a histogram which summarises 1717 data values. The data are spread out over four intervals.

If we consider the data values in order from smallest to largest, is the tenth data value in the interval 0≤x<50≤x<5 or not?

Answer:

The tenth data value in the interval 0≤x<50≤x<5.

HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

You need to count your way through the data until you reach the tenth value. For example, there are 22 data values in the first interval, so the third data value is the first (smallest) number in the second interval.

STEP: Count your way through the data to locate the tenth value
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

We need to determine if the tenth value in the data set is in the interval 0≤x<50≤x<5.

The data represented in the histogram are grouped in an ordered way. There are 22 values in the first interval, 0≤x<50≤x<5. We do not know exactly what those values are, but they have to be less than the values in the interval 5≤x<105≤x<10. For example, the first 88 values in the data set could be:

1;3;5;5;5;7;7;8or2;3;5;5;8;8;9;91;3;5;5;5;7;7;8or2;3;5;5;8;8;9;9

We don't know the value of each number in the data. But the 22 values in the first interval must be less than the 66 values in the second interval. Similarly, the values in the second interval must all be less than the values in the third interval. Based on this fact, we can count our way through the data until we locate the tenth value.

In this case, we are looking for the tenth data value. It cannot be in the first or second intervals, because together they contain 2+6=82+6=8 values in total. The tenth value is past that. Since there are 44 more values in the third interval, the tenth value must be there (the third interval starts with the ninth value and goes up to the 12th12th value). The question asks us if the tenth value is in the interval 0≤x<50≤x<5. This is the first interval, so the answer is no.

The tenth data value is not in the interval 0≤x<50≤x<5.

    [−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

    This question is about the difference between histograms and frequency polygons. This difference is small: they are exactly the same except that histograms represent the data with bars while frequency polygons show the data as a line graph.

    Histogram

    Frequency polygon

    You can see that the frequency polygon matches the shape of the histogram.

    A ✘ One is used for continuous data and one is for categorical data.
    False: Histograms and frequency polygons are both used for continuous data.
    B ✔ One uses bars and one uses lines.
    True: Histograms use bars while frequency polygons use lines.
    C ✘ One is based on grouped data and the other is not.

    Submit your answer as:

  2. Which of these statements describes a difference between histograms and bar graphs?

    A One is used for continuous data and one is used for categorical data.
    B One shows frequencies and the other does not.
    C One uses bars and one uses lines.
    D There is no difference.
    Answer:

    The correct statement is .

    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

    Histograms and bar graphs look similar but they represent different kinds of data.

    STEP: Identify the difference between histograms and bar graphs
    [−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

    Histograms and bar graphs look quite similar to each other, but they represent different types of data.

    • Histograms are used for continuous data. This means the data values can be any value in some range. In other words, the values are not necessarily separated from each other.
    • bar graphs represent categorical data. This means data that come in separate categories with nothing "between" the categories. For example, the categories might be different types of fruit. Each type of fruit is separate from other types: we cannot change a banana into a pineapple.

    Here is an example of a bar graph shown in two different ways. It shows people's favourite types of graphs. The type of graph is the category.

    Ordered by decreasing popularity

    Ordered alphabetically by category

    For a bar graph we can choose the order of the bars because the categories do not follow any particular order. And the bars do not touch because the categories are separate. For a histogram the bars must come in order. They should also touch each other because continuous data is ordered (from smallest to largest) and it does not have gaps.

    A ✔ One is used for continuous data and one is used for categorical data.
    True: Histograms show continuous data but bar graphs show categorical data.
    B ✘ One shows frequencies and the other does not.
    False: Histograms and bar graphs both show frequencies (because they count things).
    C ✘ One uses bars and one uses lines.
    False: Histograms and bar graphs both use bars.
    D ✘ There is no difference.
    False: There is a difference!

    The correct answer is choice A.

    Submit your answer as: and

  2. In statistics, correlation refers to a relationship between two quantities. This relationship might be very strong, very weak, or somewhere in between. Or it might not exist at all. There are three types of relationships:

    • Positive correlation: the quantities increase together and decrease together. This is like a linear graph with a positive gradient.
    • Negative correlation: when one of the quantities increases the other quantity decreases and vice versa. This is like a linear graph with a negative gradient.
    • Weak or no correlation: the quantities do not change in a tightly related way. For example, when one of the quantities increases the other quantity might increase and then decrease and then increase again.

    Based on the graph in Question 1, what type of correlation is there, if any, between cost per kilogram and number of kilograms sold?

    Answer:

    The bar graph and the line graph show .

    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

    Do cost per kilogram and number of kilograms sold increase together? If so, they have a positive correlation. If they move in opposite directions they have a negative correlation.

    STEP: Compare the patterns on the bar graph and the line graph
    [−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

    This question is about how cost per kilogram and number of kilograms sold are related to each other. The question describes what correlation means. Here is another way to describe it:

    • If two quantities move together (increasing together and decreasing together) they have a positive correlation.
    • If two quantities move in opposite directions (one increasing when the other decreases) they have a negative correlation.
    • If two quantities move independently of each other then there is little or no correlation between them.

    The graph shows a negative correlation: as the price of fruit goes up the amount sold goes down. They move in opposite directions. This makes sense: people buy less of the more expensive fruits.

    NOTE: You will learn how to calculate the correlation between two quantities in Grade 12.

    Cost per kilogram and number of kilograms sold have a negative correlation.

Definition: frequency polygons

The statement below is about frequency polygons. Complete the statement by choosing the best options from the lists.

Answer:

A frequency polygon is a line graph for . You can make a frequency polygon by joining all the midpoints of the top of the bars of a .

HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 2 / 2 points left]

You can read about frequency polygons here.

STEP: Complete the statement about frequency polygons
[−2 points ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

A frequency polygon is a line graph which shows the same information as a histogram. It is easy to draw a frequency polygon onto a histogram. We put a point at the top of each bar in the middle of the bar (at the midpoint of the interval).

A frequency polygon is the same as a histogram but it looks different. Instead of bars, the frequency polygon is made of lines.

Therefore the correct statement is:

A frequency polygon is a line graph for grouped data. You can make a frequency polygon by joining all the midpoints of the top of the bars of a histogram.

Frequency polygons

Frequency polygons show grouped data with a line graph. The graph below contains two frequency polygons which show the average amount of time people take to get to and from work each day in Johannesburg and Durban. Use the graph to answer the two questions which follow.

Answer:
  1. How many more commuters were there in the interval represented by 70 min70 min for Johannesburg than for Durban? .
  2. Based on the graph, are commuting times shorter in Johannesburg or Durban? .
numeric
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 3 / 3 points left]

Start by finding the frequency values for the interval centred on 70 min70 min.

STEP: Find the frequencies for the correct interval and subtract
[−2 points ⇒ 1 / 3 points left]

The first question asks us to find the difference in average daily commute for the two cities in the interval centred on 70 min70 min.

To do that, we need to subtract the frequencies for that interval.

The frequencies are 2020 for Johannesburg and 1515 for Durban. This means that 2020 people in Johannesburg have commuting times around 70 min70 min, while in Durban, 1515 people have commuting times around 70 min70 min.

To find the difference in average daily commute we subtract these numbers.

20−15=520−15=5

The difference in average daily commute in the specified interval is 55.

STEP: Identify which city is correct (if either)
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 3 points left]

For the second question we need to identify based on the graph, are commuting times shorter in johannesburg or durban. To answer this question we must focus on the horizontal axis. Moving to the right along the graph corresponds to increasing average daily commute. If a frequency polygon falls mostly on the right side then it shows relatively large average daily commute. But if a frequency polygon mostly falls on the left side, it indicates most of the average daily commute are relatively small.

So this question comes down to the shape of the two frequency polygons. Which of the frequency polygons (if either) has a peak on the left?

The answer must be Durban, because it has a peak to the left while Johannesburg has a peak to the right.

The city with the shorter average daily commute is Durban.

Histogram shapes

Suppose every student in a large class closes their eyes and holds up 11, 22, 33, 44, or 55 fingers, and then we write down how many fingers every student is showing. Which of the pictures below shows the shape we should expect for the histogram?

A

B

C

D
Answer:

The most reasonable shape to expect is choice .

HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

Do you expect most of the data values to be in the middle of the values, or will they mostly be smaller values? Or will they be spread out equally for all the values?

STEP: Think about the way the data values will be spread out
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

To answer this question, we need to think about how the data values for the number of fingers the students were showing will be spread out.

The images in the question show these four basic situations:

A

Balanced shape: Most data values are in the centre with a balanced number of values on each side. This means values in the middle are more common than values on the left side or the right side. So a balanced distribution is more or less symmetric with the peak in the middle.

B

Flat shape: All data values are spread out equally. So values on the left side are just as common as values on the right side and in the middle. This typically represents something random. Note that a flat shape is not exactly flat - but it has no significant peaks.

C

Skewed right shape: The data values are clumped up on the left side with a "tail" to the right. This shows that for some reason the data values on the right side are less common. This would happen if larger values (on the right side) are harder to achieve than smaller values (on the left side).

D

Skewed left shape: The data values are clumped up on the right side with a "tail" to the left. This shows that for some reason the data values on the left side are less common. This would happen if larger values (on the right side) are easier to achieve than smaller values (on the left side).

So which of these is the most reasonable to expect for the number of fingers the students were showing?

The number of fingers students hold up is random. There is no reason to expect that it will be a small number or that it will be a large number. The number of students who hold up 11 finger is probably going to be similar to the number of students who hold up 44 fingers. Or 55. So we should expect a flat shape.

NOTE: It is possible that the histogram will have a different shape - we can't know for sure if we do not have the data values. So our answer is based on reasonable expectations about the situation described in the question.

The most reasonable shape to expect is choice B.

Histograms vs bar graphs

  1. What is the difference between a histogram and a bar graph? Or are they the same?

    Pick your answer from the choices below.

    A Histograms show continuous quantitative data while bar graphs show categorical data.
    B Histograms show categorical data while bar graphs show continuous quantitative data.
    C Histograms show data with lines while bar graphs show data with bars.
    D There is no difference between a histogram and a bar graph.
    Answer:

    The correct description of the difference is option .

    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

    Histograms are used for data which is grouped into intervals. Bar graphs show data which is organised into categories.

    STEP: Determine what types of data are appropriate for histograms and bar graphs
    [−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

    Histograms and bar graphs are easy to confuse because they look like each other. But they are not the same! The difference is the type of data that they show.

    • Histogram A histogram uses bars to show continuous data. The data must be grouped into intervals. The bars touch each other because the data are continuous. A histogram shows the same information as a frequency polygon, but with bars instead of a line.
    • Bar graph A bar graph uses bars to show categorical data. That means data which are organised into categories. For example, types of cars or different provinces are categories. Such data cannot be grouped in intervals because the categories are separate from each other. The bars often do not touch each other because the data are not continuous.

    One key difference between histograms and bar graphs is the order of the values on the horizontal axis. The values for a histogram must be in order, because the data are continuous. But for bar graphs the order of the values can change. They can change because the categories themselves do not have a specific order.

    TIP: To decide if data belong in a histogram or a bar graph, ask yourself if the order of the data groups can be shifted or not. If the order cannot be shifted, you are dealing with a histogram situation.

    The difference between histograms and bar graphs is that histograms show continuous quantitative data while bar graphs show categorical data. The correct choice is A.

Histograms & frequency polygons

Suppose someone collects data about the number of cars sold in one month for four different car brands: BMW, VW, Toyota, and Opel.

  1. What quantity belongs on the horizontal axis if we graph this data set?
  2. Will this data set be well represented by a frequency polygon?
Answer:
  1. The quantity on the horizontal axis will be .
  2. A frequency polygon for this data set.
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 2 / 2 points left]

Remember that frequency polygons are used for showing continuous data split into a number of different intervals. If the data are not continuous, or if they cannot be broken into at least three intervals, a frequency polygon is not a good choice.

STEP: Determine if the data have the properties needed for a frequency polygon
[−2 points ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

We need to determine what quantity should go on the horizontal axis if we make a graph for the data described in the question. And we must decide if the data mentioned in the question can be represented in a frequency polygon.

These questions are related: the first question is about how the data are organised. And once we know how they are organised we will know the answer to the second question. This is because a frequency polygon requires two things:

  • The data are continuous (not categorical).
  • The data can be broken into at least 33 intervals.

To determine if the data are continuous or categorical we need to determine how the data are organised. And that comes from the quantity on the horizontal axis. If that quantity is a list of categories, the data are categorical. But if that quantity is continuous, the data are continuous.

The data in this case are about how many cars are sold in one month for different types of cars. These data are organised by the brand of the car, so they are categorical data (with four categories). So we cannot make a frequency polygon for this data set. Instead a bar chart is appropriate. There would be four bars - one for each brand.

NOTE: Any data set which is not suitable for a frequency polygon is also not suitable for a histogram.

The correct answers are:

  1. The quantity on the horizontal axis should be car brand.
  2. A frequency polygon is not appropriate for this data set.

[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

We need to identify which of the graphs shown is a bar graph.

The three graphs shown are a frequency polygon, a bar graph, and a histogram.

A

Frequency polygon: A frequency polygon is a line graph. It shows continuous data which has been grouped into intervals. A frequency polygon shows the same information as a histogram, but with lines instead of bars.

B

Bar graph: A bar graph uses bars to show categorical data. The means data which come in categories, like types of cars or different provinces. Categorical data are not grouped in intervals. The bars often do not touch each other because the data are not continuous.

C

Histogram: A histogram uses bars to show continuous data. The data must be grouped into intervals. The bars touch each other because the data are continuous. A histogram shows the same information as a frequency polygon, but with bars instead of lines.

NOTE: Bar graphs and histograms look similar and are easy to confuse. One key difference is that the order of the bars in a bar graph can be moved around because the data are not continuous. But the bars in a histogram must be in order (i.e. from smaller numbers to larger).

Matching graphs and types of data

From what kind or kinds of data would a frequency polygon be generated?

A one categorical and one quantitative
B categorical only
C quantitative only
D varies according to situation
Answer:

The correct type of data for a frequency polygon is choice .

HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 2 / 2 points left]

Think about an example of a frequency polygon. What kinds of values go on the horizontal axis? What kinds of values go on the vertical axis?

STEP: Think about an example of a frequency polygon
[−2 points ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

The question asks us to identify what type of data are used in a frequency polygon. Is it based on categorical data, quantitative data, or both? Here is some information about these data types:

  • Categorical data are organised into categories. For example, if you count the number of schools in each province, the provinces are categories. There are nine categories and each school fits into one of them. One useful fact about categorical data is that you can change the order of the categories. For the provinces, you could order them alphabetically. Or you could start with the province where you live.
  • Quantitative data are organised numerically (as numbers). For example, the heights of all the students in a class are quantitative data. Quantitative data typically follow some order, like smallest to largest.

Frequency polygons are always based on quantitative data. So a frequency polygon shows us values which are organised into intervals of numbers.

Here is an example of a frequency polygon. It shows the total number of servings of fruit eaten in a one week period for 100100 different people. It is organised by the number of servings.

The frequency polygon above shows data about how many servings of fruit people ate. The data are organised by the number of servings. The values on the horizontal axis are in order from least to greatest, and we cannot change that. We cannot change it because the data are quantitative and continuous.

Here is the original table, with explanations for each choice.

A ✘ one categorical and one quantitative
False: A frequency polygon does not show categorical data.
B ✘ categorical only
False: A frequency polygon is not used for categorical data - the data must be continuous.
C ✔ quantitative only
True: A frequency polygon shows quantitative data on both axes.
D ✘ varies according to situation
False: A frequency polygon always shows quantitative data.

The correct answer is choice quantitative only.

Imagine a histogram for the amount of time it takes many different buses to get from Durban to Nelspruit.

  1. Answer the following questions about the histogram:

    1. What quantity should go on the xx-axis of the histogram?
    2. What quantity should go on the yy-axis of the histogram?
    Answer:
    1. The quantity on the xx-axis should be: .
    2. The quantity on the yy-axis should be: .
    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 2 / 2 points left]

    Reread the question. The yy-axis on a histogram always shows the number of data values (the frequency of values). The xx-axis always shows the values for the data themselves.

    STEP: Select the correct axis labels
    [−2 points ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

    This question is about making a histogram. Specifically, we need to figure out what quantities should go on the axes for a histogram about the situation in the question.

    The horizontal axis in a histogram must always show the possible values of the data. In this case the data values are the amount of time the buses take. So the xx-axis must show time values.

    For any histogram the yy-axis always shows the number of data values in the various intervals. (This is often called the frequency.)

    For the histogram described in this question:

    1. The variable on the xx-axis should be: Time.
    2. The variable on the yy-axis should be: Number of buses.
    Submit your answer as: and

  2. Which of the pictures below shows the shape we should expect for the histogram? (Reminder: the data are about the amount of time it takes many different buses to get from Durban to Nelspruit.)

    A

    B

    C

    D
    Answer:

    The most reasonable shape to expect is choice .

    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

    Do you expect most of the time values to be in the middle of the values, or will they mostly be smaller values? Or will they be spread out equally for all the values?

    STEP: Think about the way the data values will be spread out
    [−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

    To answer this question, we need to think about how the data values for the time values will be spread out.

    The four images below show these basic situations:

    A

    Balanced shape: Most data values are in the centre with a balanced number of values on each side. This means values in the middle are more common than values on the left side or the right side. So a balanced distribution is more or less symmetric with the peak in the middle.

    B

    Flat shape: All data values are spread out equally. So values on the left side are just as common as values on the right side and in the middle. This typically represents something random. Note that a flat shape is not exactly flat - but it has no significant peaks.

    C

    Skewed right shape: The data values are clumped up on the left side with a "tail" to the right. This shows that for some reason the data values on the right side are less common. This would happen if larger values (on the right side) are harder to achieve than smaller values (on the left side).

    D

    Skewed left shape: The data values are clumped up on the right side with a "tail" to the left. This shows that for some reason the data values on the left side are less common. This would happen if larger values (on the right side) are easier to achieve than smaller values (on the left side).

    So which of these is the most reasonable to expect? The question is about how much time it takes buses to get from one city to another. Generally they will take about the same amount of time. Sometimes it will be a little faster and sometimes it will be a little slower, but most of the buses will need similar times. So the histogram should have a peak in the middle (most buses) and also smaller bars on the left (the buses which are faster) and smaller bars on the right (the buses that are slower).

    NOTE: It is possible that the histogram will have a different shape - we can't know for sure if we do not have the data values. So our answer is based on reasonable expectations about time needed for the bus trip.

    Therefore the most reasonable shape to expect is choice A.

    The most reasonable shape to expect is choice .

    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

    Do you expect most of the ratings to be in the middle of the values, or will they mostly be smaller values? Or will they be spread out equally for all the values?

    STEP: Think about the way the data values will be spread out
    [−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

    To answer this question, we need to think about how the data values for the ratings will be spread out.

    The four images below show these basic situations:

    A

    Balanced shape: Most data values are in the centre with a balanced number of values on each side. This means values in the middle are more common than values on the left side or the right side. So a balanced distribution is more or less symmetric with the peak in the middle.

    B

    Flat shape: All data values are spread out equally. So values on the left side are just as common as values on the right side and in the middle. This typically represents something random. Note that a flat shape is not exactly flat - but it has no significant peaks.

    C

    Skewed right shape: The data values are clumped up on the left side with a "tail" to the right. This shows that for some reason the data values on the right side are less common. This would happen if larger values (on the right side) are harder to achieve than smaller values (on the left side).

    D

    Skewed left shape: The data values are clumped up on the right side with a "tail" to the left. This shows that for some reason the data values on the left side are less common. This would happen if larger values (on the right side) are easier to achieve than smaller values (on the left side).

    So which of these is the most reasonable to expect? The question states that the movie is unpopular. That means we should expect that most of the ratings are low, and not many ratings will be high. So the most likely shape for the real histogram is the skewed right shape.

    NOTE: It is possible that the histogram will have a different shape - we can't know for sure if we do not have the data values. So our answer is based on reasonable expectations about ratings for an unpopular movie.

    Therefore the most reasonable shape to expect is choice C.

    The four images below show these basic situations:

Locating a specific value in a histogram

The figure below shows a histogram which summarises 1414 data values. The data are spread out over four intervals.

If we consider the data values in order from smallest to largest, is the third data value in the interval 5≤x<105≤x<10 or not?

Answer:

The third data value in the interval 5≤x<105≤x<10.

HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

You need to count your way through the data until you reach the third value. For example, there are 22 data values in the first interval, so the third data value is the first (smallest) number in the second interval.

STEP: Count your way through the data to locate the third value
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

We need to determine if the third value in the data set is in the interval 5≤x<105≤x<10.

The data represented in the histogram are grouped in an ordered way. There are 22 values in the first interval, 0≤x<50≤x<5. We do not know exactly what those values are, but they have to be less than the values in the interval 5≤x<105≤x<10. For example, the first 77 values in the data set could be:

1;1;6;8;8;8;9or1;4;5;6;8;8;91;1;6;8;8;8;9or1;4;5;6;8;8;9

We don't know the value of each number in the data. But the 22 values in the first interval must be less than the 55 values in the second interval. Similarly, the values in the second interval must all be less than the values in the third interval. Based on this fact, we can count our way through the data until we locate the third value.

In this case, we are looking for the third data value. It cannot be in the first interval, because the first interval only contains 22 data values. But there are 55 more values in the second interval, which means that the second interval includes the third value up to the seventh value. The question asks us if the third value is in the interval 5≤x<105≤x<10. This is the second interval, so the answer is yes.

The third data value is in the interval 5≤x<105≤x<10.

Histograms, frequency polygons, and bar graphs

  1. Which of these statements describes a difference between histograms and frequency polygons?

    A One uses bars and one uses lines.
    B One is used for continuous data and one is for categorical data.
    C One is based on grouped data and the other is not.
    D There is no difference.
    Answer:

    The correct statement is .

    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

    You can read about frequency polygons here.

    STEP: Identify the difference between histograms and frequency polygons
    [−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

    This question is about the difference between histograms and frequency polygons. This difference is small: they are exactly the same except that histograms represent the data with bars while frequency polygons show the data as a line graph.

    Histogram

    Frequency polygon

    You can see that the frequency polygon matches the shape of the histogram.

    A ✔ One uses bars and one uses lines.
    True: Histograms use bars while frequency polygons use lines.
    B ✘ One is used for continuous data and one is for categorical data.
    False: Histograms and frequency polygons are both used for continuous data.
    C ✘ One is based on grouped data and the other is not.
    False: Histograms and frequency polygons are both used for grouped data.
    D ✘ There is no difference.
    False: There is a difference!

    The correct answer is choice A.

    Submit your answer as:

  2. Which of these statements describes a difference between histograms and bar graphs?

    A One is used for continuous data and one is used for categorical data.
    B One uses bars and one uses lines.
    C One shows frequencies and the other does not.
    D There is no difference.
    Answer:

    The correct statement is .

    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

    Histograms and bar graphs look similar but they represent different kinds of data.

    STEP: Identify the difference between histograms and bar graphs
    [−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

    Histograms and bar graphs look quite similar to each other, but they represent different types of data.

    • Histograms are used for continuous data. This means the data values can be any value in some range. In other words, the values are not necessarily separated from each other.
    • bar graphs represent categorical data. This means data that come in separate categories with nothing "between" the categories. For example, the categories might be different types of fruit. Each type of fruit is separate from other types: we cannot change a banana into a pineapple.

    Here is an example of a bar graph shown in two different ways. It shows people's favourite types of graphs. The type of graph is the category.

    Ordered by decreasing popularity

    Ordered alphabetically by category

    For a bar graph we can choose the order of the bars because the categories do not follow any particular order. And the bars do not touch because the categories are separate. For a histogram the bars must come in order. They should also touch each other because continuous data is ordered (from smallest to largest) and it does not have gaps.

    A ✔ One is used for continuous data and one is used for categorical data.
    True: Histograms show continuous data but bar graphs show categorical data.
    B ✘ One uses bars and one uses lines.
    False: Histograms and bar graphs both use bars.
    C ✘ One shows frequencies and the other does not.
    False: Histograms and bar graphs both show frequencies (because they count things).
    D ✘ There is no difference.
    False: There is a difference!

    The correct answer is choice A.

    Submit your answer as:

  2. In statistics, correlation refers to a relationship between two quantities. This relationship might be very strong, very weak, or somewhere in between. Or it might not exist at all. There are three types of relationships:

    • Positive correlation: the quantities increase together and decrease together. This is like a linear graph with a positive gradient.
    • Negative correlation: when one of the quantities increases the other quantity decreases and vice versa. This is like a linear graph with a negative gradient.
    • Weak or no correlation: the quantities do not change in a tightly related way. For example, when one of the quantities increases the other quantity might increase and then decrease and then increase again.

    Based on the graph in Question 1, what type of correlation is there, if any, between number of units and average rental cost?

    Answer:

    The bar graph and the line graph show .

    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

    Do number of units and average rental cost increase together? If so, they have a positive correlation. If they move in opposite directions they have a negative correlation.

    STEP: Compare the patterns on the bar graph and the line graph
    [−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

    This question is about how number of units and average rental cost are related to each other. The question describes what correlation means. Here is another way to describe it:

    • If two quantities move together (increasing together and decreasing together) they have a positive correlation.
    • If two quantities move in opposite directions (one increasing when the other decreases) they have a negative correlation.
    • If two quantities move independently of each other then there is little or no correlation between them.

    The graph here shows a negative correlation. As the number of units increases the average cost decreases. They move in opposite directions. The reason is not obvious. Perhaps the buildings with fewer units have larger and more expensive flats and the buildings with lots of units have smaller units.

    NOTE: You will learn how to calculate the correlation between two quantities in Grade 12.

    Number of units and average rental cost have a negative correlation.

    NOTE: There are two different yy-axes on the graph: one on the left side (the normal position) and another one on the right side.

  2. In statistics, correlation refers to a relationship between two quantities. This relationship might be very strong, very weak, or somewhere in between. Or it might not exist at all. There are three types of relationships:

    • Positive correlation: the quantities increase together and decrease together. This is like a linear graph with a positive gradient.
    • Negative correlation: when one of the quantities increases the other quantity decreases and vice versa. This is like a linear graph with a negative gradient.
    • Weak or no correlation: the quantities do not change in a tightly related way. For example, when one of the quantities increases the other quantity might increase and then decrease and then increase again.

    Based on the graph in Question 1, what type of correlation is there, if any, between average temperature and rainfall for each month?

    Answer:

    The bar graph and the line graph show .

    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

    Do average temperature and rainfall for each month increase together? If so, they have a positive correlation. If they move in opposite directions they have a negative correlation.

    STEP: Compare the patterns on the bar graph and the line graph
    [−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

    This question is about how average temperature and rainfall for each month are related to each other. The question describes what correlation means. Here is another way to describe it:

    • If two quantities move together (increasing together and decreasing together) they have a positive correlation.
    • If two quantities move in opposite directions (one increasing when the other decreases) they have a negative correlation.
    • If two quantities move independently of each other then there is little or no correlation between them.

    The temperature decreases until the middle of the year and then increases till the end of the year. But the rainfall does its own thing. The rainfall peaks in the early part of the year (like the temperature) but then it peaks again in July when the temperature is low. In the last few months the temperature starts to rise but the rainfall is more or less flat. There is no consistent relationship between the two quantities.

    NOTE: You will learn how to calculate the correlation between two quantities in Grade 12.

    Average temperature and rainfall for each month have a weak or no correlation.

Definition: frequency polygons

The statement below is about frequency polygons. Complete the statement by choosing the best options from the lists.

Answer:

A frequency polygon is a line graph for . You can make a frequency polygon by joining all the of the top of the bars of a histogram.

HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 2 / 2 points left]

You can read about frequency polygons here.

STEP: Complete the statement about frequency polygons
[−2 points ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

A frequency polygon is a line graph which shows the same information as a histogram. It is easy to draw a frequency polygon onto a histogram. We put a point at the top of each bar in the middle of the bar (at the midpoint of the interval).

A frequency polygon is the same as a histogram but it looks different. Instead of bars, the frequency polygon is made of lines.

Therefore the correct statement is:

A frequency polygon is a line graph for grouped data. You can make a frequency polygon by joining all the midpoints of the top of the bars of a histogram.
Submit your answer as: and

Reading a histogram

Consider the histogram below. It shows data values separated into intervals from 00 up to 5656. Each interval has a width of 88.

  1. How many values are in the interval 24-32?
  2. Which interval has the most values in it? (Choose the correct interval from the choices below.)
Answer:
  1. The number of values in the bin 24-32 is: .
  2. The interval with the most values is: .
numeric
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 2 / 2 points left]

In the question, 'the number of values' means the height of each bar in the histogram. Use the vertical axis to read off the number of values for the interval you want.

STEP: Determine the number of values in the interval 24-32
[−1 point ⇒ 1 / 2 points left]

A histogram shows data values grouped into intervals. Each group (interval) is shown as a rectangle. The height of the rectangle shows the number of data values in the interval. For example, we can see below that the first interval is 0-8 and it has 1111 values in it.

The first question asks us to state the number of data values in the interval 24-32. This is the fourth interval on the histogram (from the left). The height of the fourth rectangle shows the number of data values in that interval. In this case the height is 55, so the number of data values in the interval is 55.

STEP: Identify the interval with the most values
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

The second question asks us to identify the interval with the most data values in it. This means we want the interval with the tallest rectangle. For the histrogram above, this is 16-24, which contains 1313 data values.

The correct answers are:

  1. The number of items in the interval 24-32 is: 5.
  2. The interval with the largest number of items is 16-24 .

Frequency polygons

Frequency polygons show grouped data with a line graph. The graph below contains two frequency polygons which show the heights of students at a school in Grade 8 and Grade 9. Use the graph to answer the two questions which follow.

Answer:
  1. How many more students were there in the interval represented by 158 cm158 cm for Grade 8 than for Grade 9? .
  2. Which of the groups had shorter students? .
numeric
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 3 / 3 points left]

Start by finding the frequency values for the interval centred on 158 cm158 cm.

STEP: Find the frequencies for the correct interval and subtract
[−2 points ⇒ 1 / 3 points left]

The first question asks us to find the difference in student height for the two grades in the interval centred on 158 cm158 cm.

To do that, we need to subtract the frequencies for that interval.

The frequencies are 1111 for Grade 8 and 11 for Grade 9. This means that 1111 students in Grade 8 are around 158 cm158 cm tall, while in Grade 9, 11 students are around 158 cm158 cm tall.

To find the difference in student height we subtract these numbers.

11−1=1011−1=10

The difference in student height in the specified interval is 1010.

STEP: Identify which grade is correct (if either)
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 3 points left]

For the second question we need to identify which of the groups had shorter students. To answer this question we must focus on the horizontal axis. Moving to the right along the graph corresponds to increasing student height. If a frequency polygon falls mostly on the right side then it shows relatively large student height. But if a frequency polygon mostly falls on the left side, it indicates most of the student height are relatively small.

So this question comes down to the shape of the two frequency polygons. Which of the frequency polygons (if either) has a peak on the left?

The answer must be Grade 8, because it has a peak to the left while Grade 9 has a peak to the right.

The grade with the shorter student height is Grade 8.

Histogram shapes

Suppose we have a data set for the amount of food 3737 people ate for dinner. Which of the pictures below shows the shape we should expect for the histogram?

A

B

C

D
Answer:

The most reasonable shape to expect is choice .

HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

Do you expect most of the data values to be in the middle of the values, or will they mostly be smaller values? Or will they be spread out equally for all the values?

STEP: Think about the way the data values will be spread out
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

To answer this question, we need to think about how the data values for the amount of food people ate will be spread out.

The images in the question show these four basic situations:

A

Balanced shape: Most data values are in the centre with a balanced number of values on each side. This means values in the middle are more common than values on the left side or the right side. So a balanced distribution is more or less symmetric with the peak in the middle.

B

Flat shape: All data values are spread out equally. So values on the left side are just as common as values on the right side and in the middle. This typically represents something random. Note that a flat shape is not exactly flat - but it has no significant peaks.

C

Skewed right shape: The data values are clumped up on the left side with a "tail" to the right. This shows that for some reason the data values on the right side are less common. This would happen if larger values (on the right side) are harder to achieve than smaller values (on the left side).

D

Skewed left shape: The data values are clumped up on the right side with a "tail" to the left. This shows that for some reason the data values on the left side are less common. This would happen if larger values (on the right side) are easier to achieve than smaller values (on the left side).

So which of these is the most reasonable to expect for the amount of food people ate?

Most people eat similiar amounts. Some will eat less and some will eat more. But most people dish about the same amount onto their plates, most of the time. So we should expect a balanced shape for this data set.

NOTE: It is possible that the histogram will have a different shape - we can't know for sure if we do not have the data values. So our answer is based on reasonable expectations about the situation described in the question.

The most reasonable shape to expect is choice A.

Histograms vs bar graphs

  1. What is the difference between a histogram and a bar graph? Or are they the same?

    Pick your answer from the choices below.

    A Histograms show continuous quantitative data while bar graphs show categorical data.
    B Histograms show qualitative data while bar graphs do not.
    C Histograms show categorical data while bar graphs show continuous quantitative data.
    D There is no difference between a histogram and a bar graph.
    Answer:

    The correct description of the difference is option .

    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

    Histograms are used for data which is grouped into intervals. Bar graphs show data which is organised into categories.

    STEP: Determine what types of data are appropriate for histograms and bar graphs
    [−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

    Histograms and bar graphs are easy to confuse because they look like each other. But they are not the same! The difference is the type of data that they show.

    • Histogram A histogram uses bars to show continuous data. The data must be grouped into intervals. The bars touch each other because the data are continuous. A histogram shows the same information as a frequency polygon, but with bars instead of a line.
    • Bar graph A bar graph uses bars to show categorical data. That means data which are organised into categories. For example, types of cars or different provinces are categories. Such data cannot be grouped in intervals because the categories are separate from each other. The bars often do not touch each other because the data are not continuous.

    One key difference between histograms and bar graphs is the order of the values on the horizontal axis. The values for a histogram must be in order, because the data are continuous. But for bar graphs the order of the values can change. They can change because the categories themselves do not have a specific order.

    TIP: To decide if data belong in a histogram or a bar graph, ask yourself if the order of the data groups can be shifted or not. If the order cannot be shifted, you are dealing with a histogram situation.

    The difference between histograms and bar graphs is that histograms show continuous quantitative data while bar graphs show categorical data. The correct choice is A.

    Submit your answer as:

    is more appropriate.

    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

    STEP: Compare the data to the information in Question 1
    [−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

    In Question 1 we found that bar graphs are used for categorical data and histograms are used for continuous quantitative data. So to answer this question we need to figure out which type of data we have.

    The data are about how many people were born each day for 100100 days. And the question states that the data are organised by number of births. This is the key! This tells us that the data are organised on a numeric scale. And we can group them into intervals. So we are dealing with continuous quantitative data and the graph should be a histogram.

    Here is an example of what the histogram might look like (with invented numbers):

    Notice that the values on the horizontal axis are in order from least to greatest, and we cannot change that. This is normal for a histogram because the data are quantitative and continuous.

    The correct choice is A histogram.

Histograms & frequency polygons

Suppose someone collects data about the number of cars sold in one month for four different car brands: BMW, VW, Toyota, and Opel.

  1. What quantity belongs on the horizontal axis if we graph this data set?
  2. Will this data set be well represented by a frequency polygon?
Answer:
  1. The quantity on the horizontal axis will be .
  2. A frequency polygon for this data set.
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 2 / 2 points left]

Remember that frequency polygons are used for showing continuous data split into a number of different intervals. If the data are not continuous, or if they cannot be broken into at least three intervals, a frequency polygon is not a good choice.

STEP: Determine if the data have the properties needed for a frequency polygon
[−2 points ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

We need to determine what quantity should go on the horizontal axis if we make a graph for the data described in the question. And we must decide if the data mentioned in the question can be represented in a frequency polygon.

These questions are related: the first question is about how the data are organised. And once we know how they are organised we will know the answer to the second question. This is because a frequency polygon requires two things:

  • The data are continuous (not categorical).
  • The data can be broken into at least 33 intervals.

To determine if the data are continuous or categorical we need to determine how the data are organised. And that comes from the quantity on the horizontal axis. If that quantity is a list of categories, the data are categorical. But if that quantity is continuous, the data are continuous.

The data in this case are about how many cars are sold in one month for different types of cars. These data are organised by the brand of the car, so they are categorical data (with four categories). So we cannot make a frequency polygon for this data set. Instead a bar chart is appropriate. There would be four bars - one for each brand.

NOTE: Any data set which is not suitable for a frequency polygon is also not suitable for a histogram.

The correct answers are:

  1. The quantity on the horizontal axis should be car brand.
  2. A frequency polygon is not appropriate for this data set.

Matching: types of graphs

Which one of the three graphs below shows a histogram?

A

B

C
Answer:

The histogram is option .

HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

Think about an example of a histogram. What kinds of values go on the horizontal axis? What kinds of values go on the vertical axis?

STEP: Identify the histogram
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

We need to identify which of the graphs shown is a histogram.

The three graphs shown are a bar graph, a histogram, and a frequency polygon.

A

Bar graph: A bar graph uses bars to show categorical data. The means data which come in categories, like types of cars or different provinces. Categorical data are not grouped in intervals. The bars often do not touch each other because the data are not continuous.

B

Histogram: A histogram uses bars to show continuous data. The data must be grouped into intervals. The bars touch each other because the data are continuous. A histogram shows the same information as a frequency polygon, but with bars instead of lines.

C

Frequency polygon: A frequency polygon is a line graph. It shows continuous data which has been grouped into intervals. A frequency polygon shows the same information as a histogram, but with lines instead of bars.

NOTE: Bar graphs and histograms look similar and are easy to confuse. One key difference is that the order of the bars in a bar graph can be moved around because the data are not continuous. But the bars in a histogram must be in order (i.e. from smaller numbers to larger).

We are looking for the histogram, which is option B.

Submit your answer as:

Matching: types of graphs

Which one of the three graphs below shows a bar graph?

A

B

C
Answer:

The bar graph is option .

HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

Think about an example of a bar graph. What kinds of values go on the horizontal axis? What kinds of values go on the vertical axis?

STEP: Identify the bar graph
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

We need to identify which of the graphs shown is a bar graph.

The three graphs shown are a frequency polygon, a bar graph, and a histogram.

A

Frequency polygon: A frequency polygon is a line graph. It shows continuous data which has been grouped into intervals. A frequency polygon shows the same information as a histogram, but with lines instead of bars.

B

Bar graph: A bar graph uses bars to show categorical data. The means data which come in categories, like types of cars or different provinces. Categorical data are not grouped in intervals. The bars often do not touch each other because the data are not continuous.

C

Histogram: A histogram uses bars to show continuous data. The data must be grouped into intervals. The bars touch each other because the data are continuous. A histogram shows the same information as a frequency polygon, but with bars instead of lines.

NOTE: Bar graphs and histograms look similar and are easy to confuse. One key difference is that the order of the bars in a bar graph can be moved around because the data are not continuous. But the bars in a histogram must be in order (i.e. from smaller numbers to larger).

We are looking for the bar graph, which is option B.

What do we know?

The histogram below summarises how many hours 3131 different families spend watching television in a week. The results are grouped into 55 intervals which are all 10 hours10 hours wide. Data values are both integers and non-integers.

  1. What is the minimum number of families for whom the number of hours spent watching television was greater than 50 hours50 hours?
  2. What is the maximum number of families for whom the number of hours spent watching television was greater than 50 hours50 hours?
Answer:
  1. The minimum is .
  2. The maximum is .
numeric
numeric
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 2 / 2 points left]

The question includes the boundary value 5050. You need to identify which interval the given boundary is in, or which intervals it is between.

STEP: Determine the minimum and maximum number of values which can be above 5050
[−2 points ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

When dealing with grouped data, it is important to be able to know how many data values there are above or below a given value on the xx-axis. In this question we need to figure out the minimum and maximum number of families for whom the number of hours spent watching television was above 50 hours50 hours.

The boundary is the lower boundary of the first interval. Most of the data values must be above 5050. In fact, all 3131 values could be greater than 5050. But we cannot know for sure: they could all be above 5050 but it is also possible the values in the first interval are all equal to 5050 (not greater than). So the number of values above 5050 must be at least 2727 but could be as many as 3131.

The minimum number of values is 2727 and the maximum is 3131.

When dealing with grouped data, it is important to be able to know how many data values there are above or below a given value on the xx-axis. In this question we need to figure out the minimum and maximum number of people for whom data usage was below 287 megabytes287 megabytes.

5. Pie charts

Calculating degrees for a sector in a pie chart

Answer the two questions below about this pie chart.

  1. Calculate the missing value represented by xx.
  2. How many degrees is sector xx? (Round your answer to two decimal places)
Answer:
  2. °°
one-of
type(fraction.unsimplified)
numeric
STEP: Find the value of xx
[−2 points ⇒ 2 / 4 points left]

Remember the “pie” represents some kind of whole, which is made up of the slices. Add up all the slices and we get the complete pie. Here the slices known as sectors are divided into values represented as fractions. All the fractions have the same denominator; thus, to get whole "pie", we need to end up with a value like this: 17171717. This evaluates to 1, the whole pie. So xx will be 817817.

STEP: Find the size of sector xx
[−2 points ⇒ 0 / 4 points left]

To find the number of degrees a sector should be in a pie chart you can follow these steps:

  • Find the total amount used in the data in this case it was 17
  • What ratio of this total is represented by this sector? Here it was 817817
  • Multiply your ratio with 360 °° (Remember a full revolution = 360 °°)
Sector°=817×360°=169,41°Sector°=817×360°=169,41°

So xx has a fraction value of 817817, which is the same as 169,41°°.

So when we are looking for the highest value, we need to find the highest percentage on the pie chart. Then we check in the legend which name corresponds with the colour of that sector.

The district with the greatest water consumption is Amatole because it has the largest percentage (37%37%). And the district with the lowest water consumption is Chris Hani because it has the smallest percentage (7%7%).

[−2 points ⇒ 0 / 4 points left]

For Question 3 we need to calculate the range. Remember the range is calculated by taking the highest value from the data and subtracting the lowest value from that.

Range=Highest value - Lowest value=55−8=47%Range=Highest value - Lowest value=55−8=47%

Therefore:

  1. The district which uses the most water is Amatole.
  2. The district which uses the least water is Cacadu.
  3. The range is 4747%%.

STEP: Find the value of xx
[−2 points ⇒ 2 / 4 points left]

In a pie chart, the size of each sector is proportional to the quantity it represents. If we add up all the percentages for each sector then we get 100%. This is like adding up all the slices of a pie and getting a whole pie.

All the sectors added100x=15+38+1+24+x=15+38+1+24+x=22All the sectors added=15+38+1+24+x100=15+38+1+24+xx=22
